Alejandro Flores Lamas

Email: alexfloreslamas@gmail.com

About Me

Hello, I’m Alejandro, a PhD in Computer Science. My research focuses on analysing and designing algorithms for graphs, with a recent interest in approximation algorithms and parameterised complexity. I am also involved in studying string constraint algorithms.

At CICESE, I acquired essential skills that have contributed significantly to my professional development, including time management, communication, and teamwork. My experience as a PhD student at CICESE was immensely gratifying and played a pivotal role in shaping my career.

Postdoctoral experience

Royal Holloway, University of London

Postdoctoral Research Assistant

2020 - 2023

https://www.royalholloway.ac.uk/

The focus of this project was on the handling of strings in software systems. Existing research relying on regular expressions to study strings often overlooks important features in modern programming languages. This project bridges such a gap by enhancing theoretical understanding and practical implementation.

  • Supervisor: Prof. Matthew Hague.
  • Project: String Constraint Solving with Real-World Regular Expressions.
  • Supported by: The Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council, EPSRC [EP/T00021X/1].

Projects

A dynamic programming algorithm for a maximum s-clique set on trees

https://alexfloreslamas.github.io/maximum-s-clique-set-on-trees.io/

Clique finding in networks is a fundamental problem graph problem. To overcome the limitations of strict cliques, a relaxed version called s-cliques is studied. The s-clique allows for greater flexibility in modelling relationships such as social concepts. Finding the largest s-clique in an arbitrary graph is computationally challenging. Here we propose a dynamic programming algorithm that efficiently solves such a problem on an n-vertex tree in O(s⋅n) time for s≥ 2, outperforming existing methods. This advancement paves the way for finding maximum s-cliques in less restrictive graphs. We use Python, Pandas, YAML and NetworkX for the project’s scripts. We also provide a small set of artificial and real trees (along with corresponding credits) for experimentation.

RegexFinder (Draft)

https://www.cs.rhul.ac.uk/home/uhac208/Regex_Survey/RS.html

This project involves a brief report on regular expressions (regex) within the NPM package manager for JavaScript. To extract the data, we developed a Ruby script called ‘RegexFinder.rb’. The input can be either the NPM installation directory or a set of JavaScript files, and the output includes details about regex usage. The information is displayed on the screen and can be saved as markdown or PDF files.
